title: Colorful primates don't have better color vision, study finds
description: Primate species with better color vision are not more likely to have red skin or fur coloration, as previously thought.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Peru's Operation Mercury stopped most illegal gold mining in one biodiversity hotspot—then the COVID-19 pandemic hit
description: Artisanal and small-scale gold mining is a lifeline for many who live in Madre de Dios, a region in southeastern Peru, where poverty is high and jobs are scarce. But the economic development in this part of the Amazon basin comes at a cost, as it causes deforestation, build up of sediment in rivers, and mercury contamination in nearby watersheds, threatening public health, Indigenous peoples, and the future of the biodiversity hotspot. And much of the mining activity is unauthorized.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Diamond materials as solar-powered electrodes: Spectroscopy shows what's important
description: It sounds like magic: photoelectrodes could convert the greenhouse gas CO2 back into methanol or N2 molecules into valuable fertilizer—using only the energy of sunlight.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Conceptual study looks at nanocapsules for scaling up the power of nanotechnology
description: In a new study, researchers at the University of Missouri have created a proof of concept of a nanocapsule—a microscopic container—capable of delivering a specific "payload" to a targeted location.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researcher uncovers how stereotypes about brilliance shape women's decisions to study psychology or philosophy
description: Even though women in high school and college tend to outperform men academically, they still internalize the stereotype that brilliance is more linked to men. This belief affects their choice of major and perpetuates gender gaps in academic fields, according to a new study by a Florida State University researcher.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Teacher well-being not a priority in schools, experts warn
description: Against a backdrop of funding shortages and recruitment issues across the education sector, two education experts argue that equipping leaders with more soft skills will improve mental health and well-being in school staff.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows simulator, combined with app, helps teachers correct mistakes before entering classroom
description: When pilots, surgeons or others with high-stakes professions are learning their craft, they have simulators with which to practice. Now, a new study shows that a simulator, when combined with software to provide data on performance, can help teachers learn what mistakes to avoid before working with working in a real classroom.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Quiet cables set to help reveal rare physics events
description: Imagine trying to tune a radio to a single station but instead encountering static noise and interfering signals from your own equipment. That is the challenge facing research teams searching for evidence of extremely rare events that could help understand the origin and nature of matter in the universe. It turns out that when you are trying to tune into some of the universe's weakest signals, it helps to make your instruments very quiet.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers ready NASA's SPHEREX space telescope for 2025 launch
description: NASA's SPHEREx space telescope has been tucked inside a custom-built chamber on and off for the past two months undergoing tests to prepare it for its two-year mission in space. SPHEREx, which stands for Spectro-Photometer for the History of the universe, Epoch of Reionization and Ices Explorer, is set to launch into orbit around Earth no later than April 2025.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: One in three children who've been in care system enter youth justice system, UK research shows
description: An unprecedented study of 2.3m children has found that one in three children born between 1996 and 1999 who had experience of the care system received a youth justice caution or conviction between the ages of 10 and 17, compared with just 4% of those without experience of care.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Jewel of the forest: New electric blue tarantula species discovered in Thailand
description: In an exciting discovery, a new species of tarantula with electric blue coloration was found in Thailand.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Evaluating the shear viscosity of different water models
description: Water is one of the most abundant substances on Earth and partakes in countless biological, chemical, and ecological processes. Thus, understanding its behavior and properties is essential in a wide variety of scientific and applied fields. To do so, researchers have developed various water models to reproduce the behavior of bulk water in molecular simulations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hundreds of weeds found illegally advertised online in Australia
description: Hundreds of weeds have been found advertised on a public online marketplace in Australia. Cacti and pond plants were among the most frequently advertised illegal weed species. These weeds are prohibited in Australia due to their harmful impact on the country's environment and agriculture. Despite this, a research team led by Jacob Maher discovered thousands of online advertisements for these weeds. Their study is published in the open access journal NeoBiota.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Generative AI already being used in majority of college classrooms, according to new survey
description: A new report from Wiley suggests that generative artificial intelligence (AI) is already being used in the majority of college classrooms—and that number could climb quickly.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nanoparticle vaccine candidate shows promise against emerging tick-borne virus in early studies
description: Cleveland Clinic researchers have used nanoparticles to develop a potential vaccine candidate against Dabie Bandavirus, formerly known as Severe Fever with Thrombocytopenia Syndrome Virus (SFTSV), a tick-borne virus that currently has no prevention, treatment or cure.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Two new species of ancient primates resembling lemurs identified
description: Fossil evidence from the Tornillo Basin in West Texas and the Uinta Basin in Utah reveals two new species of omomyids—a family of small-bodied early primates from the Eocene epoch. The findings also clarify previously disputed taxonomic distinctions among these primates, according to researchers from The University of Texas at Austin, Des Moines University in Iowa and Midwestern University in Arizona.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Profiling artemisinin's antimalarial mechanism: Research team reveals crucial target proteins
description: Jigang Wang and colleagues have made significant progress in unraveling the antimalarial mechanisms of artemisinin (ART) and its derivatives. Their latest research, published in the journal Engineering, sheds light on the crucial target proteins and pathways of ART, providing valuable insights into combating malaria and addressing emerging ART resistance.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Avoiding the 'nothingburger' effect in government contractor mergers and acquisitions
description: In love and business alike, the laws of attraction can be obscure. Companies pursue mergers and acquisitions (M&A) for a host of reasons ranging from gaining market share to gaming the tax system. In his recently published research, Brett Josephson, associate dean for executive development and associate professor of marketing at George Mason University, pondered one particularly mysterious M&A motivator: customer strategy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New Indo-European language discovered during excavation in Turkey
description: An excavation in Turkey has brought to light an unknown Indo-European language. Professor Daniel Schwemer, an expert for the ancient Near East, is involved in investigating the discovery.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Understanding the role of pareidolia in early human cave art
description: A psychological phenomenon where people see meaningful forms in random patterns, such as seeing faces in clouds, may have stimulated early humans to make cave art.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Exotic tree species in the forest mean loss of grazing land for reindeer
description: Semi-domesticated reindeer avoid winter habitats with exotic lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta), introduced from Northern America. Reduced food supply and dense stands probably contribute to the reindeers' avoidance behavior of areas with tall P. contorta-trees. This is reported by researchers from Umeå University and the Swedish University of Agriculture, SLU in the journal Forest Ecology and Management.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Lolita the orca's ashes are going home for a traditional water ceremony: Here's what will happen
description: Lolita, the orca who lived in a tank at the Miami Seaquarium from her capture in 1970 in waters off Washington state to her death 53 years later in August, will be honored in a homecoming Saturday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The silver lining to storm surge: How some baby fish ride out hurricanes to success
description: Humans loathe the deadly impact of storm surge, and for good reason. But new research shows how juvenile tarpon and snook can actually benefit from it. In turn, scientists are learning how to design more eco-friendly developments that help the fish survive.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research reveals surprising influences on an employee's intention to quit
description: Research in the International Journal of Enterprise Network Management reveals unexpected factors that influence an employee's intentions to quit their job in information technology. The findings challenge the received wisdom and could shed light on the dynamic role of online professional networking and social media profile updates.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: El Niño and La Niña: What's it all about?
description: It's official: An El Niño event is now underway across the Pacific.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hidden ocean the source of carbon dioxide on Jupiter moon: Research
description: Carbon dioxide detected on Jupiter's moon Europa comes from the vast ocean beneath its icy shell, research using James Webb Space Telescope data indicated on Thursday, potentially bolstering hopes the hidden water could harbor life.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA's Atmospheric Waves Experiment completes space environment tests
description: NASA's Atmospheric Waves Experiment (AWE) has successfully completed critical space environment tests. Planned for launch to the International Space Station in November 2023, AWE will study atmospheric gravity waves in Earth's atmosphere to help us better understand the connections between terrestrial weather and space.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Conversations with plants: Can we provide plants with advance warning of impending dangers?
description: Imagine if humans could "talk" to plants and pre-warn them of approaching pest attacks or extreme weather.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Curbing violence in Mexico: Disrupting cartel recruitment holds the key, new study finds
description: Not through courts and not through prisons. The only way to reduce violence in Mexico is to cut off recruitment. Increasing incapacitation instead leads to both more homicides and cartel members, researcher Rafael Prieto-Curiel from the Complexity Science Hub and colleagues show in a study published in Science.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Global study reveals extensive impact of metal mining contamination on rivers and floodplains
description: A study, published in Science, has provided new insights into the extensive impact of metal mining contamination on rivers and floodplains across the world, with an estimated 23 million people believed to be affected by potentially dangerous concentrations of toxic waste.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Overfishing and climate change impacts on New Zealand's fish populations were hidden—until now
description: Pelagic-oceanic fish commonly caught in warmer waters, such as skipjack tuna and blue mackerel, have been increasing in New Zealand's waters since the 1950s, while cold-water species such as southern bluefin tuna display strong reductions in overall catch from the 1970s onwards, new research has found.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The dance of organ positioning: A tango of three proteins
description: In order to keep track of their environment, cells use cilia, antenna-like structures that can sense a variety of stimuli, including the flow of fluids outside the cell. Genetic defects that cause cilia to malfunction and lose their sensory abilities can result in disorders known as "ciliopathies," including polycystic kidney diseases, but they can also disrupt the correct asymmetric positioning of internal organs during embryonic development—what is known as "organ laterality."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using harmless light to change azobenzene molecules with new supramolecular complex
description: Azobenzenes are incredibly versatile and have many potential uses, such as in making tiny machines and improving technology as well as making light controllable drugs. This molecule can switch between two different forms by light. However, the two forms are in equilibrium, which means that a mixture present that prevents optimal use for applications.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bridging the gap: New terrain smoothing method refines downslope windstorm modeling
description: Researchers from the UK Met Office, in collaboration with the Chinese Academy of Meteorological Sciences, have developed an advanced terrain-smoothing technique that significantly improves the modeling of downslope windstorms. This innovative approach, detailed in a recent study published in the Journal of Advances in Atmospheric Sciences, offers enhanced accuracy and detail in simulating complex weather phenomena.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Video: Firefoxes and whale spouts light up Earth's shield
description: Did you know the Northern lights or Aurora Borealis are created when the mythical Finnish "firefox" runs so quickly across the snow that its tail causes sparks to fly into the night sky?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chicago's West Side is an air pollution hotspot, new study finds
description: The western edge of Chicago—including the North and South Lawndale, East Garfield Park, Archer Heights and Brighton Park neighborhoods—experiences up to 32% higher concentrations of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) air pollution compared to the rest of the city, a new Northwestern University study has found.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How racism shapes Black motherhood in the US
description: Being a mom is hard. Being a Black mom is especially hard. A new study from North Carolina State University underscores the ways that being a Black mother in the United States involves navigating aspects of parenthood that are explicitly tied to dealing with anti-Black racism.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Achromatic diffractive liquid-crystal optics for virtual reality displays
description: As a promising candidate for the next-generation mobile platform, mixed reality (MR) such as Apple Vision Pro and Meta Quest Pro (both are passthrough virtual reality headsets) has the potential to revolutionize the way we perceive and interact with various digital information.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Exploring Earth's mantle through microseisms
description: The ocean is constantly whirring with activity. The pressure from this constant roiling and swelling is one cause of microseisms—random, nearly imperceptible vibrations of Earth that also can be produced by human activities like vehicular traffic.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Investigating invasive plants as roadside contaminant removal tools
description: Tall, densely growing Phragmites and cattail (Typha) are familiar plants alongside highways and byways in the northern United States, flourishing in salty roadsides and degraded wetland environments created by chemicals applied to roads in the colder months known as deicers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers call for change to Irish schoolyards to support children's play
description: Researchers are calling for increased attention to the design of schoolyards and provision of diverse spaces for play in primary schools, to address issues of exclusion, bullying and racism in Irish schoolyards.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Suicide in Ghana: Society expects men to be providers. A new study explores this pressure
description: Suicide is a complex behavior that is widely regarded as a significant public health issue across the globe. It is influenced by psychiatric, psychological, biological, social, cultural, economic and existential factors. In most countries, the rate of male suicides is between 3 and 7.5 times higher than that of females even though suicide ideation (thoughts) and attempts are more frequent for females.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Curiosity about religion is viewed as morally virtuous, new research finds
description: People from diverse religious backgrounds in the United States view curiosity about religion as morally virtuous, according to new research published in Social Psychological and Personality Science. Atheists also view this curiosity as moral, although less moral than a lack of religious curiosity.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: First contact could turn out well for humanity
description: You've heard this story before. An advanced alien race comes to Earth. They offer peace and prosperity, but they hold a dark secret. One that could destroy humanity. That dark secret has varied over the years, from stealing our water, books on culinary advice, or communism, but the result is always the same. First contact with advanced extraterrestrials goes very badly for us. But in reality, how bad could it be? That's the question a new study examines using game theory and Hobbesian philosophy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: We should be looking for small, hot Dyson spheres, new paper argues
description: In 1960, legendary physicist Freeman Dyson published his seminal paper "Search for Artificial Stellar Sources of Infrared Radiation," wherein he proposed that there could be extraterrestrial civilizations so advanced that they could build megastructures large enough to enclose their parent star.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Innovative solution for poultry litter waste management uses photocatalytic titanate nanofibers
description: The shift away from using poultry litter for crop fertilization has transformed this once-valuable agricultural byproduct into an environmental liability for poultry producers. Addressing this challenge, a study led by Dr. Jun Zhu from the University of Arkansas offers an innovative approach using photocatalytic titanate nanofibers (TNFs) to degrade organic pollutants in anaerobic digestate, a byproduct of poultry litter.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Tröger's base derived 3D-porous aromatic frameworks for near-unity selectivity of CO2 photoconversion
description: The global energy crisis is exacerbated by the continuous consumption of fossil fuels during the rapid development of modern industries. In addition, the survival and development of human beings is also being seriously affected by the emission of greenhouse gases.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers reveal origins of zirconium nitride's superior performance
description: A group of researchers have unraveled the mysteries behind a recently identified material—zirconium nitride (ZrN)—that helps power clean energy reactions. Their proposed framework will help future designs for transition metal nitrides, paving a path for generating cleaner energy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Mussels able to adjust heart rate to cope with marine heat waves
description: Mussels are among the ultimate superfoods, high in vitamin B12, omega-3 and great for the heart. Now, new research shows they are also likely to withstand marine heat waves by adjusting their body functions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Five golden rules for effective science communication: Perspectives from a documentary maker
description: Over the past three years, people from all walks of life have learned a great deal about different branches of science. The COVID-19 pandemic introduced many of us to information about virology and vaccine production. Environmental disasters in every part of the world have brought concepts from meteorology and climatology to daily news reports.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Viewpoint: German police have long collaborated with energy giant RWE to enforce ecological catastrophe
description: In early 2023, the German village of Lützerath was the site of violent clashes between thousands of protesters and police who wanted to clear the village so it could be swallowed up by Garzweiler II, a huge opencast coal mine. In small groups, police forces charged into groups of protesters, beating people, kicking and pushing them to the ground. Police dogs attacked protesters, just meters away from the steep edge of the Garweiler II opencast coal mine. Dozens of people were injured.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Box of donated artifacts turns out to be treasure trove of Neanderthal bones
description: A team of historians, paleontologists and biologists affiliated with institutions across Spain has discovered that a box of artifacts donated to a museum in Spain back in 1986 contained a treasure trove of Neanderthal bones. In their paper published in the journal Frontiers in Earth Science, the group describes the history of the bones, how they turned up at a museum and what the group has learned about the objects so far.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Split gene-editing tool offers greater precision
description: To make a gene-editing tool more precise and easier to control, Rice University engineers split it into two pieces that only come back together when a third small molecule is added.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Autonomous systems help NASA's Perseverance do more science on Mars
description: A computer pilot helps NASA's six-wheeled geologist as it searches for rock samples that could be brought to Earth for deeper investigation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Your unique body odor could identify who you are and provide insights into your health, all from the touch of a hand
description: From the aroma of fresh-cut grass to the smell of a loved one, you encounter scents in every part of your life. Not only are you constantly surrounded by odor, you're also producing it. And it is so distinctive that it can be used to tell you apart from everyone around you.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Age, not class, is now the biggest divide in British politics, new research confirms
description: "Class is the basis of British politics; all else is embellishment and detail." So wrote Peter Pulzer, the former Gladstone professor of politics at the University of Oxford in the 1960s. Nowadays, however, it is age, not social class, that is the biggest demographic division in Britain's electoral politics.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The UK rejoining the Horizon research funding scheme benefits Europe too, researcher says
description: The UK has just rejoined the EU's flagship research funding programs, Horizon Europe and Copernicus. This is great news for science, the EU and the UK.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Traffic tickets can be profitable, and fairness isn't the bottom line in city courts where judges impose the fines
description: When city governments spend more money than they take in, officials often search for ways to generate revenue. One increasingly common source of money is traffic tickets. And research shows police officers issue more traffic tickets when cities are financially in a deficit.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Idea of green growth losing traction among climate policy researchers, survey of nearly 800 academics reveals
description: When she took to the floor to give her State of the Union speech on 13 September, European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen largely stood by the script. Describing her vision of an economically buoyant and sustainable Europe in the era of climate change, she called on the EU to accelerate the development of the clean-tech sector, "from wind to steel, from batteries to electric vehicles." "When it comes to the European Green Deal, we stick to our growth strategy," von der Leyen said.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Why it is so difficult for people to come forward with sexual assault allegations
description: When writer E. Jean Carroll was asked why she finally went public—after more than 25 years—to accuse then U.S. president Donald Trump of sexual assault, her response was something that countless others have thought: "Think of how many women have come forward and nothing happens."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Big businesses say they are helping to restore ecosystems, but proof remains elusive
description: We're witnessing first-hand an alarming decline of the world's ecosystems, which is having a devastating impact on the people who rely on them. In many cases, it's no longer enough to just protect what remains—degraded ecosystems must be restored.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Towards a better understanding of early human embryonic development
description: The onset of embryo-specific gene transcription, also known as embryonic genome activation (EGA), is a crucial step in the developmental journey of an organism. Although EGA has been studied to some extent in mice, human EGA remains largely unexplored, mainly due to the lack of novel in vitro cell models and ethical restrictions on the usage of human embryos.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers develop first method to study microRNA activity in single cells
description: MicroRNAs are small molecules that regulate gene activity by binding to and destroying RNAs produced by the genes. More than 60% of all human genes are estimated to be regulated by microRNAs; therefore, it is not surprising that these small molecules are involved in many biological processes including diseases such as cancer.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study on the genetic magnetization of living bacteria shows great potential for biomedicine
description: Magnetic bacteria possess extraordinary capabilities due to the magnetic nanoparticles, the magnetosomes, which are concatenated inside their cells. A research team at the University of Bayreuth has now transferred all of the approximately 30 genes responsible for the production of these particles to non-magnetic bacteria in a broad series of experiments.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Freshwater quality is one of New Zealanders' biggest concerns. Water-trading 'clubs' could be part of the solution
description: For more than 25 years, New Zealanders have consistently rated freshwater health as one of their leading environmental concerns. But the issue is strikingly absent from the 2023 election campaign.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How Canada can make its startup ecosystem more inclusive
description: The global pandemic caused devastating economic impacts, including high levels of unemployment. As with the 2008 recession, self-employment has been encouraged as a pathway towards economic participation and boosting the labor market.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Women used to be more likely to vote Conservative than men but that all changed in 2017—research wants to find out why
description: In many nations in the immediate post-war period, women were more often supporters of rightwing parties than men. This "traditional" gender gap was supposedly underpinned by women's greater religiosity and lower exposure to the social institutions of the left, such as trade unions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ancient pictograph vandalism at Bon Echo Provincial Park reveals ongoing disregard for Indigenous history
description: Vandalism has once again marred the ancient Indigenous pictographs nestled within Bon Echo Provincial Park about two hours west of Ottawa and north of Kingston, Ont.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Australia has officially given up on eradicating the Varroa mite. Now what?
description: The federal government body in charge of pest control has announced Australia will abandon efforts on eradicating the Varroa mite.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers' analysis of perching birds points to new answers in evolutionary diversification
description: When Charles Darwin traveled to the Galapagos Islands almost 200 years ago as a gentleman naturalist, he used the power of observation to develop his theory that species evolve over time.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists reveal intricate mechanisms cells use to build protein destruction signals
description: Within the intricate molecular landscape inside of a cell, the orchestration of proteins demands precise control to avoid disease. While some proteins must be synthesized at specific times, others require timely breakdown and recycling. Protein degradation is a fundamental process that influences cellular activities such as the cell cycle, cell death, or immune response.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using satellite data to enhance global food security
description: Accurate estimates and forecasts of crop area and yield play an important role in guiding policy decisions related to food security, especially in light of the growing impacts of climate change. IIASA researchers and colleagues highlight the value of integrating remote sensing and data sharing for timely agricultural information critical for food security and sustainability planning in a new paper.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nanoparticles made from plant viruses could be farmers' new ally in pest control
description: A new form of agricultural pest control could one day take root—one that treats crop infestations deep under the ground in a targeted manner with less pesticide.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Dinosaur feathers reveal traces of ancient proteins
description: Paleontologists at University College Cork (UCC) in Ireland have discovered X-ray evidence of proteins in fossil feathers that sheds new light on feather evolution.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change may affect 40% of biodiversity in semi-arid portion of Brazil's Northeast by 2060
description: The consequences of climate change in the Caatinga, the semi-arid shrubland and thorn forest biome in Brazil's Northeast region, will include species loss, substitution of rare plants by more generalist vegetation, biotic homogenization (in which previously distinct plant communities become progressively more similar), increasing aridity, and even desertification in some areas.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists design fresh tomatoes suitable for mechanical harvesting
description: According to a study published in Nature Plants, Chinese scientists have elucidated the mechanism of fruit shape formation in tomatoes and have developed fresh tomatoes for mechanical harvesting.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: In helium-three, superfluid particles pair 'like a dance in space'
description: Picture a nanoscale dance floor full of independently moving particles. When things really start to heat up—or, in this case, cool down—particles partner off, but on opposite sides of the space, "dancing" in synch as if telepathically.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: One-atom-thick phosphorus/arsenic alloy ribbons could improve batteries, solar cells and sensors
description: Researchers at UCL have created one-atom-thick ribbons made of phosphorus alloyed with arsenic that could dramatically improve the efficiency of devices such as batteries, supercapacitors and solar cells.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New nanopore tech for quicker, more thorough mRNA quality checks
description: Researchers at The University of Queensland are harnessing the latest sequencing technology developed by UK-based biotech Oxford Nanopore Technologies to analyze mRNA vaccines and therapies.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Material would allow users to 'tune' windows to block targeted wavelengths of light
description: Researchers have demonstrated a material for next generation dynamic windows, which would allow building occupants to switch their windows between three modes: transparent, or "normal" windows; windows that block infrared light, helping to keep a building cool; and tinted windows that control glare while maintaining the view.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Greenwashing: A threat to a 'nature positive' world
description: Researchers have identified the threat greenwashing poses to a "nature positive" world, one where environmental decline halts and biodiversity outcomes improve. The research is published in Nature Ecology & Evolution.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New origin story for key regulatory gene: PRC2 repressed jumping genes in ancestors of eukaryotes
description: The key protein complex PRC2 was discovered decades ago to silence genes, but new findings by Frederic Berger and his group at the Gregor Mendel Institute show that PRC2 represses transposons in a range of eukaryotes and only gradually evolved to silence genes. The study was published on September 21 in the journal Current Biology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Parasitic plant convinces hosts to grow into its own flesh—it's also an extreme example of genome shrinkage
description: If you happen to come across plants of the Balanophoraceae family in a corner of a forest, you might easily mistake them for fungi growing around tree roots. Their mushroom-like structures are actually inflorescences, composed of minute flowers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ultrathin films achieve record hydrogen-nitrogen separation
description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of materials that contain nano-sized pores. These pores give MOFs record-breaking internal surface areas, which make them extremely versatile for a number of applications: separating petrochemicals and gases, mimicking DNA, producing hydrogen, and removing heavy metals, fluoride anions, and even gold from water are just a few examples.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: We could sequester CO2 by 're-greening' arid lands, plant scientists say
description: Reducing CO2 levels in the atmosphere will take more than cutting emissions—we will also need to capture and store the excessive volumes of already-emitted carbon. In an opinion paper published in the journal Trends in Plant Science on September 21, a team of plant scientists argue that arid lands such as deserts could be one answer to the carbon-capture problem.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA tech lets scientists see snow water through the trees
description: NASA scientists are testing a technology that could more accurately measure water stored in snow as seen from a satellite in orbit.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Riddle of varying warm water inflow in the Arctic now solved
description: In the "weather kitchen," the interplay between the Azores High and Icelandic Low has a substantial effect on how much warm water the Atlantic transports to the Arctic along the Norwegian coast. But this rhythm can be thrown off for years at a time.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A fossil jumping spider's 15-million-year journey
description: Jumping spiders (Salticidae) are a recently evolved family of spiders. They are known for their distinctive large eyes and ability to jump long distances relative to their small size. Australia has about 1,200 to 1,500 species of this spider family. Only 500 have scientific names.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Six new species of Western Australian trilobites discovered
description: Six new species of trilobites have been found deep underground in the Canning Basin of Western Australia. Dr. Patrick Smith at the Australian Museum and Heidi Allen from Geological Survey of WA tell us how this discovery has reshaped our understanding of ancient life and geological time in the region.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Novel filter uses carbon nanotubes to create new paradigm for dialysis membranes
description: A collaborative team has developed a new type of filter for kidney dialysis machines that can clean the blood more efficiently and improve patient care. Piran Kidambi, assistant professor of chemical and biomolecular engineering, led the team, which included William Fissell, associate professor of nephrology and hypertension at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Shuvo Roy, professor of bioengineering at University of California, San Francisco, and Francesco Fornasiero, biosciences and biotechnology staff scientist at Lawrence Livermore National Lab.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study paves the way for new class of nanoscale devices, new opportunities in photonics
description: Non-Hermitian systems have numerous alluring optical properties at exceptional points (EPs) and have attracted extensive attention because of their great prospects in applications such as optical sensing, integrated optics, and other fields.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: From forming embryo to cancer metastasis: The significance of collective cell movement
description: Against all expectations, the most common tissue in our bodies behaves differently at different length scales. That's what physicist Luca Giomi discovered in his research into the flow of cells. "Our findings are even more interesting than we hoped for."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Accelerated warming has pushed North America's deepest lake across important ecological thresholds
description: A team of researchers from Queen's University and Environment and Climate Change Canada have shown that accelerated 21st-century warming has triggered a striking shift in algal composition in the Great Slave Lake, North America's deepest lake, and one of the world's iconic "northern Great Lakes."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Unveiling the science of ultrasound-driven microbubble desorption
description: Injecting drugs into the bloodstream can often harm healthy tissues as well. Drug delivery systems (DDSs) are an innovative solution designed to target specific cells and minimize such side effects. One strategy for drug delivery that has steadily gained traction involves a combination of microbubbles and ultrasound.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ancient 'power' palazzo on Rome's Palatine Hill reopens to tourists, decades after closure.
description: An ancient Roman imperial palazzo atop the city's Palatine Hill was reopened to tourists on Thursday, nearly 50 years after its closure for restoration.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Team resolves molecular switching behavior of azonium compounds for light-controlled drugs
description: Molecules that change shape under the influence of light can be used as switches in biomedical applications, for instance to inhibit an enzyme. An international team of researchers, including chemists at the Universities of Amsterdam and Groningen, have now resolved the fundamentals of the molecular switching behavior of a specific class of switchable molecules called azonium compounds.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New imaging technique detects virus movement in unprecedented detail
description: Proteins are the workhorses of biological systems, carrying out their work with extraordinary precision and speed. For years, observing proteins in action has been a significant challenge, as imaging methods often lacked sufficient speed and resolution to capture their elegant but swift dances.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Topological materials open a new pathway for exploring spin hall materials
description: A group of researchers have made a significant breakthrough which could revolutionize next-generation electronics by enabling non-volatility, large-scale integration, low power consumption, high speed, and high reliability in spintronic devices.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Technique for 3D printing metals at the nanoscale reveals surprise benefit
description: Late last year, Caltech researchers revealed that they had developed a new fabrication technique for printing microsized metal parts containing features about as thick as three or four sheets of paper.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Disrupting a core metabolic process in T cells may improve their therapeutic efficacy
description: In exploring an aspect of how killer T cells generate the raw materials required for their proliferation, a Ludwig Cancer Research study has uncovered an unexpected link between the immune cells' metabolism, regulation of gene expression, persistence and functional efficacy that could be exploited using existing drugs to improve cancer immunotherapy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New Type I supernova discovered with JWST
description: Using the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), an international team of astronomers has observed the galaxy cluster PLCK G165.7+67.0. The observational campaign resulted in the detection of a new Type I supernova. The finding is reported in a paper published September 13 on the pre-print server arXiv.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Tiny bubbles could reveal immune cell secrets and improve treatments
description: Macrophages are cells vital to the immune system and could possibly inform cell-based therapies for a variety of medical conditions. However, realizing the full potential of macrophage therapies relies on being able to see what these cellular allies are doing inside our bodies, and a team of Penn State researchers may have developed a way to watch them do their thing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A model probing the connection between entangled particles and wormholes in general relativity
description: Quantum entanglement is a physical process through which pairs of particles become connected and remain so even when separated by vast distances. This fascinating phenomenon has been the focus of numerous research studies, due to its mysterious nature and promising real-world applications.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Long-lasting La Niña events more common over past century
description: Multiyear La Niña events have become more common over the last 100 years, according to a new study led by University of Hawai'i (UH) at Mānoa atmospheric scientist Bin Wang. Five out of six La Niña events since 1998 have lasted more than one year, including an unprecedented triple-year event. The study was published in Nature Climate Change.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research finds that sewage release is worse for rivers than agriculture
description: Ahead of World Rivers Day (24 September), new research by the University of Oxford reveals that sewage discharge into rivers has a greater impact on water quality, and the animals and plants that live in rivers, than surrounding land use. The findings have been published in the journals Global Change Biology and Ecological Solutions and Evidence.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
